text: You get the name and you say, "Great, can you make me an e-intro? Actually even better. Can you connect me over text?" So one tip that I have for all founders, all sales leaders, everyone out there, stop using email. Email is where deals go to die. Text message is where deals get done.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks Sahil for tactical advice on closing deals during turbulent market conditions. Sahil is explaining his strategy for leveraging existing customers to get warm introductions to new prospects. He emphasizes that instead of just collecting names of potential customers from existing clients, salespeople should push for immediate text message introductions rather than traditional email introductions, arguing that email creates friction while text messages create urgency and accountability.
text_ko: 이름을 받으면 “좋아요, 이메일 소개(e-intro) 해주실래요? 사실 더 좋다면 문자(text message)로 연결해주실 수 있나요?”라고 말하게 되죠. 그래서 창업자든, 영업 리더든, 모든 분들께 드리고 싶은 팁 하나 있어요. 이메일 사용을 그만하세요. 이메일은 딜이 죽는 곳이에요. 딜은 문자(text message)에서 성사돼요.
text_zh: 你拿到名字后就说："太好了，能帮我做个电子介绍吗？其实更好的是，能不能微信上直接拉个群？"所以我给所有创始人、销售负责人，还有大家的一个建议就是，别再用邮件了。邮件是交易的坟墓，微信才是成交的地方。
text_es: Consigues el nombre y dices: "Perfecto, ¿me puedes hacer una presentación por email? Mejor aún, ¿me puedes conectar por mensaje de texto?" Entonces, un consejo que tengo para todos los fundadores, todos los líderes de ventas, para todos: dejen de usar email. El email es donde van a morir los negocios. Los mensajes de texto son donde se cierran los deals.

text: So the way I think about setting up a plan when you have limited visibility and some major headwinds is setting up a really conservative plan and then having milestones, short term milestones that unlock the ability to lean into growth and spend based on hitting those targets.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks Sahil about how founders should approach forecasting and quota setting during uncertain market conditions. Sahil has just shared data showing that 76% of companies missed their Q3 targets and over 80% are expected to miss Q4 goals. He's explaining his recommended approach to planning for 2023 when traditional forecasting becomes nearly impossible due to market volatility and limited visibility into future performance.
text_ko: 가시성(visibility)이 제한되고 큰 역풍(headwinds)이 있을 때 제가 계획을 세우는 방식은, 우선 아주 보수적인 계획(conservative plan)을 세워두고 단기 마일스톤(short-term milestones)을 두어서 그 목표들을 달성하면 성장(lean into growth)에 본격적으로 투자하고 지출(spend)을 늘릴 수 있는 여지를 여는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得在能见度有限、又面临重大阻力的情况下制定计划，最好的做法就是先设定一个相对保守的计划，然后设置一些短期里程碑(milestones)，一旦达到这些目标，就可以加大投入去追求增长。
text_es: Entonces, la forma en que veo el tema de armar un plan cuando tienes poca visibilidad y vientos en contra importantes es crear un plan bien conservador y después tener hitos, metas a corto plazo que te permitan acelerar el crecimiento y aumentar la inversión cuando logres esos objetivos.

text: Sales comp plans are stuck in the stone ages. They're stuck in the world of Glengarry Glen Ross, Boiler Room, Wolf of Wall Street, get the dollar in through the door. What we haven't done is built a modern technical sales compensation plan that actually aligns the needs and incentives of the business, the customer and the rep.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks Sahil about compensation plans for salespeople during the current market downturn. Sahil has just explained how traditional sales compensation rewards short-term revenue generation without considering customer retention or long-term value. He argues that sales compensation plans haven't evolved to match modern business priorities, particularly the recent shift from growth-at-all-costs to sustainable, profitable growth with high retention rates.
vocabulary_highlights: get the dollar in through the door
text_ko: 영업 보상 제도(sales comp plans)가 아직도 석기시대에 머물러 있어요. Glengarry Glen Ross나 Boiler Room, Wolf of Wall Street 같은 분위기에서 ‘일단 돈만 들여오면 된다’는 식이죠. 우리가 아직 못한 건 회사와 고객, 그리고 영업 담당자(rep)의 필요와 인센티브를 실제로 일치시키는 현대적이고 기술적인 영업 보상 플랜을 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 销售提成方案还停留在石器时代呢。还在用《大亨游戏》、《锅炉房》、《华尔街之狼》那套老思路，就是不管三七二十一先把钱收进来再说。我们一直没有搞出一个现代化的技术型销售薪酬体系，能真正把公司需求、客户需求和销售代表的激励机制统一起来。
text_es: Los planes de compensación de ventas están en la edad de piedra. Siguen atascados en el mundo de Glengarry Glen Ross, Boiler Room, El Lobo de Wall Street, con esa mentalidad de "haz que entre el dinero como sea". Lo que no hemos logrado es crear un plan de compensación técnico y moderno que realmente alinee las necesidades e incentivos del negocio, el cliente y el vendedor.

text: So something interesting we saw is that from November until March of last year, companies were basically blowing out their quota, sales reps were blowing out their quota. All of a sudden everything came to a screeching halt in April, and April, May and June were really tough times.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks about forecasting and quotas during market uncertainty. Sahil is sharing real-time data from Bravado's 300,000-member sales community to illustrate how dramatically and unpredictably market conditions changed throughout 2022. He's explaining the challenge of planning when performance can shift so quickly, as companies went from exceeding targets to missing them within months, making traditional annual forecasting nearly impossible.
text_ko: 한 가지 흥미로운 건 작년 11월부터 3월까지는 회사들이 사실상 쿼터(quota)를 다 뚫었고, 영업사원들(sales reps)도 쿼터를 훌쩍 넘겼다는 점이에요. 그런데 갑자기 4월에 모든 게 확 멈췄고, 4월·5월·6월은 정말 힘든 시기였어요.
text_zh: 我们发现了一个很有意思的现象，去年11月到3月这段时间，各家公司基本上都超额完成了销售指标，销售代表们的业绩都特别好，远超预期。结果到了4月份突然就急刹车了，4、5、6月这三个月日子过得特别艰难。
text_es: Algo muy interesante que notamos es que desde noviembre hasta marzo del año pasado, las empresas estaban superando sus cuotas por mucho, los vendedores estaban reventando sus objetivos. De repente todo se paró en seco en abril, y abril, mayo y junio fueron meses súper duros.

text: Take your best sales people and make them CSMs. There's no point. There's no point in having your best salespeople sell. What's the point if people aren't going to buy anyway? If they do, they're going to buy in onesie, twosies, not these big enterprise deals.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks Sahil about strategies for retaining existing customers during the market downturn. Sahil has just explained that cold outreach response rates are at historic lows and enterprise sales cycles are dramatically longer. He's making his most controversial recommendation - moving top sales talent from new business acquisition to customer success management (CSM) roles, arguing that retaining existing customers is more valuable than pursuing difficult-to-close new deals in the current market.
text_ko: 가장 잘하는 영업사원들을 고객 성공 매니저(CSMs)로 만들라는 건 의미 없어요. 최고의 영업사원들을 굳이 영업에 붙여놔도 소용없어요 — 사람들이 어차피 사지 않을 텐데요. 설사 산다 해도 한두 건 정도밖에 안 사고, 큰 엔터프라이즈 딜(enterprise deals)은 기대하기 어려워요.
text_zh: 把你最厉害的销售拿去做客户成功经理(CSM)。这样做没意义。让你最牛的销售去卖东西根本没意义。有什么用呢？反正客户也不会买。就算买，也就是零零散散买一点，不会是那种大企业单子。
text_es: Toma a tus mejores vendedores y hazlos CSMs. No tiene sentido. No tiene caso tener a tus mejores vendedores vendiendo. ¿De qué sirve si la gente no va a comprar de todas formas? Y si compran, van a comprar de poquito en poquito, no estos grandes contratos empresariales.

text: You got to change the rules of the game and start to think about the problem differently. I think that not enough founders do that. They just kind of bash their heads against the wall with the same kind of preconceived notions of what success may or may not look like.
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks about the importance of continued growth during tough market conditions. Sahil is explaining how Bravado innovated by creating "Bravado Flex," a commission-only sales model that worked during the downturn when traditional full-time hiring stopped. He's arguing that companies need fundamental innovation rather than minor optimizations when market conditions change dramatically, using his own company's pivot as an example of successful rule-changing.
vocabulary_highlights: change the rules of the game
bash their heads against the wall
text_ko: 판을 바꿔서 문제를 다르게 생각하기 시작해야 해요. 그런데 그렇게 하는 창업자가 충분히 많지 않은 것 같아요. 많은 분들이 성공이 어떤 모습일지에 대한 고정관념에 매달려서 같은 방식으로 계속 벽에 부딪히기만 해요.
text_zh: 你得改变游戏规则，换个思路去看问题。我觉得很多创始人都没做到这一点。他们就是拿着那些老想法，觉得成功应该是什么样子，然后一头撞南墙，撞到底也不回头。
text_es: Tienes que cambiar las reglas del juego y empezar a ver el problema desde otro ángulo. Creo que muy pocos fundadores hacen eso. Simplemente se dan de cabezazos contra la pared con las mismas ideas preconcebidas de cómo debería verse o no el éxito.

text: Sales when done well doesn't feel weird, okay? If it ever feels weird, you're a bad salesperson. I've been selling now for 14 years. I've sold literally hundreds, millions of dollars worth of deals. I could pretty much call any customer I've ever sold to and have a conversation with them and it would say, "How's it going?"
speaker: Sahil Mansuri
context: Lenny asks for more tactical advice on closing deals during difficult market conditions. Sahil is about to tell the story of how he sold to Facebook at Glassdoor, but first he's establishing his philosophy that great salespeople build genuine friendships, not just transactional relationships. He's explaining that successful sales should feel natural and valuable to both parties, setting up the context for his Facebook story which demonstrates this principle in action.
text_ko: 영업(sales)을 잘하면 전혀 어색하지 않아요, 알겠죠? 만약 어색하게 느껴진다면 그건 영업을 못하는 거예요. 저는 14년 동안 영업을 해왔고, 말 그대로 수백 건—총액으로는 수백만 달러 규모의 거래를 성사시켰어요. 전에 거래했던 고객이라면 거의 누구한테나 전화를 걸어 '요즘 어떻게 지내세요?' 하고 편하게 대화할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 销售做得好的话根本不会让人觉得别扭，明白吗？如果你觉得别扭，那说明你不是个好销售。我做销售已经14年了，成交的单子加起来有几百万美金。我基本上可以给任何一个老客户打电话聊天，就像"最近怎么样啊？"这种感觉。
text_es: Las ventas, cuando se hacen bien, no se sienten raras, ¿vale? Si alguna vez se siente raro, es que eres mal vendedor. Llevo vendiendo ya 14 años. He cerrado literalmente cientos de deals por millones de dólares. Prácticamente puedo llamar a cualquier cliente al que le haya vendido algo y tener una conversación normal con él, saludarlo con un "¿Qué tal todo?"
